Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I woke up early, determined to vote before work. My mom was making breakfast, but her eyes looked tired. I remembered to ask, “Is everything okay at home?” She hesitated, then admitted Dad had been feeling down lately, and she was worried. I felt the weight of her words, knowing she needed me to listen, maybe even stay a bit longer. But I glanced at the clock—if I left now, I’d have time to vote and still get to work on time. I checked my wallet for my ID, but realized I’d grabbed the wrong one. I could go back for the right card later, but that would mean coming home after work, when my parents might be asleep. My mom’s hopeful eyes met mine, silently asking for comfort. At the same time, I felt the civic pressure to vote, to do my part. My heart tugged in two directions—toward my family’s needs and my responsibility as a citizen. I stood in the kitchen, torn, unsure which role to answer first.
